data.title: Album Review: Out Of Our Heads â€“ The Music of Kooman and Dimond
data.meta_description: â€œI'm not like the otherÂ girls in the show'Â Â  Albums that are made up of selections from
data.text:
â€œIâ€™m not like the other girls in the showâ€

Albums that are made up of selections from the catalogue of musical theatre writers, as opposed to straight soundtracks, tend to fit into a generally similar format, as my experience of listening to quite a few this year has borne out. And by and large, I can tell whether I am going to like it the album on the strength of the comedy song â€“ for there is always a comedy song â€“ and sure enough, when it came to Out Of Our Heads â€“ The Music of Kooman and Dimond (alt iTunes link here), so this rule came to pass. Pleasingly enough, that song â€“ Random Black Girl â€“ comes in as the second track and is an absolute corker both musically tight and lyrically hilarious and thus overall, I really enjoyed the album.

Michael Kooman and Christopher Dimond are something of an up and coming pair of US musical theatre writers with a handful of shows to their names â€“ Golden Gate, Dani Girl and Homemade Fusion â€“ that have been bubbling under whilst they build up their name and reputation. They seem on the right track as this CD, a selection of their songs, features a line-up of exciting Broadway, including at least one name that should be familiar to UK theatre-goers in the fabulous (baby) Patina Miller who headed up Sister Act here and is reprising the role back over the ocean.

â€˜Random Black Girlâ€™ is an obvious highlight with its acutely observed lyrics about the trials of being a woman of colour working on Broadway â€“ â€œevery crowd must have at least one person, who doesnâ€™t happen to be whiteâ€ â€“ and it works because Kooman has composed a big, ballsy tune and Dimondâ€™s lyrics never forget to be highly witty and in the immortal words of Karen Walker, itâ€™s funny cos itâ€™s true. And of course Miller sings the hell out of it, making it an instant classic. Millerâ€™s other track on the CD is another great song, a duet with Anderson Davis on â€˜The Temp and the Receptionistâ€™ â€“ initially another entry in the comedy genre â€“ its subtitle is â€œThe Cubicle of Loveâ€ after all â€“ but this tale of a burgeoning nerdish office romance actually has a giant heart and its warm emotion is guaranteed to put a huge smile on your face.

The blurb for the album states that these songs â€œblur the lines between musical theater [sic] and popâ€ but I have to say I think it feels very strongly a musical theatre album and it is the better for it. The song-writing here throws up many nuggets of stories as opposed to the more generic emotion that one might associate with pop songs â€“ Matt Doyleâ€™s falling in love tumbling for â€˜Lucyâ€™s Laughâ€™ is gorgeous, Anderson Davisâ€™ beautifully solemn â€˜Lost In The Wavesâ€™, the angst-ridden passion behind Kyle Dean Masseyâ€™s â€˜Walking Without Youâ€™ â€“ this is a classy set of songs. The mood is lightened by numbers like Christopher Sieberâ€™s â€˜In Excessâ€™ or the mellower drivetime ambience of Chris Mannâ€™s â€˜Driftâ€™.

Thereâ€™s lots of fun to be had with Out Of Our Heads, the humour and tunefulness of so many of these songs makes it an irrepressible listen and one which I have happily replayed several times. Not having previously been aware of Kooman and Dimond, I was a tiny bit gutted to see that a production of their song cycle Homemade Fusion was actually part of this yearâ€™s Edinburgh Festival. The YouTube clips indicate just how much fun these songs are live â€˜The Temp and the Receptionistâ€™ and â€˜Random Black Girlâ€™ are naturally my favourites, and so I will definitely be on the lookout to see if it emerges anywhere in London and if anyone has Ms Millerâ€™s number, could you ask her to nip back here for the night especially ğŸ˜‰ Until then, fans of new musical theatre could do a lot worse than investigating this CD.
